columns.text: In this problem, we will determine if the firm will profit from selling its asset and identify at what rate the firm just break-even.

We will consider following the following details from the problem in solving the requirements.

| Particulars         |          |
|---------------------|----------|
| Future value        | $145,000 |
| Rate                | 11%      |
| Period (years)      | 4        |
| Cost of acquisition | $91,700  |

For the first requirement, determine if the firm will profit from selling the asset.

To determine if selling the asset is profitable for the firm, let's first calculate the present value of selling the asset four years from now. The present value refers to the current value of future cash flow, considering the interest rate and the period.

In calculating the present value, the future value is multiplied by the rate and period factor. Hence, we will use the following formula in solving the future value of selling the asset.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value} &=\dfrac{{FV}}{\left(1 + r\right)^{t}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which refers to the cash value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate

Let's now calculate if selling the asset is profitable for the firm.
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Profit} &= \$95,516-\$91,700
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$3,816}
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, based on our calculation, if the firm sells its asset four years from now, it will generate a $3,816 profit.**

Next, we will identify at what rate the firm breaks even for the following requirement.

The breakeven rate is when the firm generates zero profit from selling the asset but does not incur any losses.

In finding the break-even rate, we will utilize the spreadsheet function RATE.

The rate function is a financial function that calculates the rate based on the period, present value, and future value. The rate spreadsheet formula is as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
RATE&=(nper,pmt,pv,[fv],[type]) \\
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

$nper$, which refers to the period\
$pmt$, which means the constant payment\
$pv$, which represent the present value\
$fv$, the future value\
$type$, which indicates the basis of the calculation, either year-end or beginning of the year

Let's now calculate the rate in the spreadsheet. Note that the present value should be negative for the function to work correctly.

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/8e8240cf-ea6c-433b-9bd4-147af2ed7e92-1642268387211754.png)

**Therefore, the break-even rate where the firm does not profit from selling the asset is 12.14%.**
To conclude, the firm will generate an income of $3,816 from selling the asset, and the break-even point on selling the asset is 12.14%.
